text.headline: Development of the Toyota Production System (TPS)
text.text: Key milestones in the evolution of TPS, from jidoka and just-in-time roots to global diffusion and formalization.

text.headline: 1902 – Jidoka concept is born
text.text: Sakichi Toyoda patents a loom that stops automatically when a thread breaks, establishing the jidoka principle of building quality into the process.

text.headline: 1926 – Toyota Industries founded
text.text: Toyota Industries Corporation is founded to manufacture and sell automatic looms, providing the industrial base that later funds automotive production and TPS.

text.headline: 1933 – Automotive department established
text.text: An automobile department is created within Toyoda Automatic Loom Works, marking the start of Toyota’s automotive manufacturing activities.

text.headline: 1937–1938 – Toyota Motor & early Just-in-Time
text.text: Toyota Motor Corporation is established (1937). At the Koromo/Honsha plant, Kiichiro Toyoda introduces a just-in-time production concept (1938), a direct precursor of TPS’s JIT pillar.

text.headline: 1943 – Taiichi Ohno joins Toyota Motor
text.text: Taiichi Ohno transfers from Toyoda Automatic Loom to Toyota Motor Corporation. He will later drive the creation and refinement of TPS.

text.headline: 1947–1949 – Machine shop experiments
text.text: As machine shop manager, Ohno rearranges machines into product flow, introduces multi-process handling, reduces work-in-process, and empowers workers to stop the line, prototyping future TPS practices.

text.headline: 1950 – Financial crisis and labor dispute
text.text: A severe financial crisis and labor dispute at Toyota force management to pursue dramatic productivity and quality improvements, accelerating TPS development.

text.headline: Early 1950s – TPS building blocks refined
text.text: In the early 1950s, Ohno and colleagues refine visual control, suggestion systems, small lot production, quick changeovers, production leveling, and kanban ideas that become core TPS mechanisms.

text.headline: 1956 – Shigeo Shingo begins P-Course at Toyota
text.text: Industrial engineer Shigeo Shingo starts regular training at Toyota, shaping SMED (single-minute exchange of die) and poka-yoke, which support TPS’s focus on flow and defect prevention.

text.headline: 1957 – Basic Andon system introduced
text.text: Toyota introduces a basic andon system using lights to signal problems at the line, making jidoka visible and enabling rapid response to abnormalities.

text.headline: 1962 – Company-wide pull & kanban completed
text.text: Toyota completes a company-wide internal pull system and kanban implementation, and begins using kanban with major suppliers, making TPS an integrated production system.

text.headline: 1965 – Deming Prize for Quality
text.text: Toyota receives the Deming Prize, recognizing its quality management system, which is tightly linked to TPS practices and philosophy.

text.headline: 1969 – Operations Management Consulting Division
text.text: Toyota establishes an internal Operations Management Consulting Division to spread TPS thinking and practices within Toyota and its affiliates.

text.headline: 1973 – Oil shock validates TPS
text.text: During the global oil crisis, Toyota remains profitable while many automakers struggle, drawing international attention to TPS as a robust, efficient production system.

text.headline: 1975 – First English TPS handbook drafted
text.text: An internal TPS handbook by Sugimori, Cho, Ohno and others is drafted in English, documenting the system more systematically and preparing it for wider dissemination.

text.headline: 1984 – NUMMI joint venture in the U.S.
text.text: The NUMMI joint venture between Toyota and General Motors in California becomes a high-profile demonstration of TPS in an American context, influencing global interest in lean manufacturing.

text.headline: 1988 – Ohno’s TPS book in English
text.text: Taiichi Ohno’s book “Toyota Production System: Beyond Large-Scale Production” is published in English, offering a primary explanation of TPS to practitioners worldwide.

text.headline: 1992 / 1998 – Official TPS booklet issued
text.text: Toyota publishes its first official booklet describing TPS in 1992, later revised in 1998. The booklet defines TPS as a framework for conserving resources by eliminating waste.

text.headline: 2001 – “The Toyota Way 2001”
text.text: Toyota issues “The Toyota Way 2001,” formally codifying the principles of continuous improvement and respect for people that underpin TPS and guide management behaviors.
